title: Calls for Adelaide University merger cost to be publicly released | ABC NEWS
description: There are fresh calls for the new Adelaide University to reveal the true cost of its creation.  A recent senate inquiry was told the figures couldn't be publicly released, but new documents reveal a major contract is not "commercial in confidence" as previously stated. title: 50,000 Opticomm customers set to lose free-to-air TV, and face regular internet outages | ABC NEWS
description: Customers of a private fibre-optic network provider say in addition to experiencing regular internet outages, some are also losing access to free-to-air television over their existing technology.   The changes to free-to-air television will impact about 50,000 Opticomm customers across the country, while internet issues are being felt more widely. Grace Atta has this report for Stateline Northern Territory.   Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Search of burnt Hong Kong towers could take up to a month | ABC NEWS
description: Hong Kong authorities have warned its search of the Wang Fuk Court apartment buildings in Tai Po could take up to a month due to the difficult working environment.  Hong Kong Police’s Cheng Ka-Chun says low light has hindered search efforts.  Hong Kong’s anti-corruption body has arrested 11 people so far as investigations are underway into the use of foam blocks to seal windows and non-compliant materials in scaffolding and defunct fire alarms. Meanwhile, China’s national security officials have warned Hong Kong dissidents against plunging the territory into further chaos after a student was arrested on suspicion of inciting sedition. title: Pope Leo arrives in Lebanon on Middle East tour | ABC NEWS
description: Pope Leo has touched down in Lebanon on his first international tour of his papacy. The head of the Catholic Church will hold a holy mass at the Beirut waterfront, pray at the iconic Martyr Square and visit the Monastery of Saint Sharbel.  Crowds who are welcoming him hope his presence will bring a degree of security and world attention to the Middle Eastern country amid simmering tensions between Hezbollah and Israel. title: The overdose risk that forced a vitamin B6 crackdown | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Every day millions of Australians take vitamin supplements, hoping for a health boost.    But there’s been a sharp rise in people suffering numbness, nerve damage, even paralysis, after accidentally overdosing on vitamin B6.    Many don’t even realise B6 is in so many products at high concentrations and that the vitamin can build up in the body.    Today, reporter for the ABC’s 7.30 program Tom Hartley unpacks his year-long investigation into the surge in cases and the regulator’s long-overdue crackdown.    Featured:    Tom Hartley, 7.30 reporter

title: National home values rise by 1 per cent or more for third straight month | ABC NEWS
description: Australia’s national housing prices have increased for a third consecutive month with home values in mid-sized capitals leading the charge.  Cotality’s Eliza Owen says more job opportunities and lower living expenses in Perth, Brisbane and Adelaide have drawn more migration from Sydney and Melbourne, but increased demand has been met with constrained supply in these smaller metropolises. title: US says Ukraine needs sovereignty and security in any peace plan with Russia | ABC NEWS
description: US and Ukrainian officials have met in Miami to talk about a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine. US Secretary of State Marco Rubio says the meeting was "very productive", but more work is needed. It follows two weeks of negotiations that began with a US blueprint for peace that critics said initially favoured Russia. title: Smart cars weaponised by domestic violence abusers | ABC NEWS
description: Internet-connected cars are being weaponised for abuse by perpetrators of family and domestic violence, prompting calls for manufacturers to embed more safety features in their systems. In one example a woman's car had a "kill switch" activated that prevented her from driving beyond a 1 kilometre radius from her home. title: Death toll from flooding and landslides in South East Asia and Sri Lanka reaches 800 | ABC NEWS
description: At least 800 people have been killed in floods across South East Asia and Sri Lanka.  Sri Lankan President Anura Kumara Dissanayake labels Cyclone Ditwah as the worst disaster in the country’s history, with the military deployed to assist flood-ravaged communities. Meanwhile, heavy rain and gale-force winds have slammed Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia after a rare tropical storm formed in the Malacca Strait. title: Australia could face blackouts with the closure of coal-fired power stations | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO) warns the energy grid is not ready for the closure of the Eraring coal plant in NSW.  The rise of rooftop solar has raised the threat of surges that could cause widespread blackouts without supporting infrastructure. Infrastructure to stabilise the grid is not due to be installed until after 2027, when Eraring closes. title: Newcastle port cancels all shipping movements due to protest | ABC NEWS
description: NSW police have arrested 141 people who attempted to block the shipping channel in Newcastle Harbour during Rising Tide protests, which began on Thursday.  Three people suspended themselves from a bulk carrier and unfurled a banner on Sunday morning. Protesters will remain at a campsite at Foreshore Park until Tuesday.  Via ABC News NSW. title: Netanyahu seeks presidential pardon over corruption charges | ABC NEWS
description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has formally requested a pardon from Israeli President Isaac Herzog over charges of bribery, fraud and breach of public trust.  Netanyahu argued his exemption from criminal justice process would be in the country’s national interest.  The move marks a backflip from his previous position after US President Donald Trump expressed support for a pardon. Dr Ronit Leveine-Schnur says a pardon during ongoing trials is ‘problematic’ for the rule of law and democracy.
